Line 1: Line 1: â
[[Image:Ubuntu 8.04.png|thumb|right|[[Ubuntu (Linux distribution)|Ubuntu]], a popular Linux Distribution]]
+
[[Image:Ubuntu 8.04.png|thumb|right|[[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]], a popular Linux Distribution]]
A '''Linux distribution''' (also called '''GNU/Linux distribution''' and often simply '''[[Software_distribution|distribution]]''' or '''[[distro]]''') is a member of the [[Linux]] family of [[Unix-like]] computer [[operating system]]s. Such systems are built from the [[Linux kernel]] and assorted other packages, such as the [[X Window System]] and software from the [[GNU project]]. Distributions optimized for size tend to use more compact alternatives like [[busybox]], [[uclibc]] or [[dietlibc]]. These distributions consist of a large variety of software and use the kernel Linux. There are currently over three hundred [[List of Linux distributions|Linux distributions]] in active development, constantly being revising and improved.
A '''Linux distribution''' (also called '''GNU/Linux distribution''' and often simply '''[[Software_distribution|distribution]]''' or '''[[distro]]''') is a member of the [[Linux]] family of [[Unix-like]] computer [[operating system]]s. Such systems are built from the [[Linux kernel]] and assorted other packages, such as the [[X Window System]] and software from the [[GNU project]]. Distributions optimized for size tend to use more compact alternatives like [[busybox]], [[uclibc]] or [[dietlibc]]. These distributions consist of a large variety of software and use the kernel Linux. There are currently over three hundred [[List of Linux distributions|Linux distributions]] in active development, constantly being revising and improved.
